dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, you know that feeling, right? You buy something online, it's not quite right, and then you're stuck in refund limbo, waiting forever for your money back?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, you know that feeling, right? You buy something online, it's not quite right, and then you're stuck in refund limbo, waiting forever for your money back?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Ugh, yes! It's the absolute worst. Like, seriously, the most annoying part of online shopping.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ugh, yes! It's the absolute worst. Like, seriously, the most annoying part of online shopping.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. But I just read about this San Francisco startup, Returnly, that's trying to tackle that specific headache.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. But I just read about this San Francisco startup, Returnly, that's trying to tackle that specific headache.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A San Francisco-based startup called Returnly is seeking to solve at least a portion of the headachenamely, the payment delayby issuing instant store credit when you decide you dont want an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, I've heard whispers! Aren't they doing something with instant store credit?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I've heard whispers! Aren't they doing something with instant store credit?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A San Francisco-based startup called Returnly is seeking to solve at least a portion of the headachenamely, the payment delayby issuing instant store credit when you decide you dont want an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They're saying they can issue instant store credit for like, 85% of customers, on the spot. [overlaps] Without even having received the item back yet!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! They're saying they can issue instant store credit for like, eighty five percent of customers, on the spot. Without even having received the item back yet!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Whoa, wait, *before* you've even put it in the mail? That's a game-changer. How do they do that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa, wait, before you've even put it in the mail? That's a game-changer. How do they do that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they assess your risk. So they know who to trust, I guess. And the idea is, you get your credit instantly, so you can just buy the right thing right away.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they assess your risk. So they know who to trust, I guess. And the idea is, you get your credit instantly, so you can just buy the right thing right away.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's super smart. I mean, uh, think about it, you're not waiting, you're just re-spending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's super smart. I mean, uh, think about it, you're not waiting, you're just re-spending.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And that's precisely what happens! Apparently, nine out of ten customers order a second item *before* they've even shipped the first one back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that's precisely what happens! Apparently, nine out of ten customers order a second item before they've even shipped the first one back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nine in ten have ordered a second item before they even shipped the first unwanted item back, the company says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No way! And, um, they probably end up spending more too, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No way! And, um, they probably end up spending more too, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You got it. The article says they're likely to outspend the original order by 23%! The founder even said it's a better shopping experience, so consumers buy more.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You got it. The article says they're likely to outspend the original order by twenty three percent! The founder even said it's a better shopping experience, so consumers buy more.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Theyre likely to outspend the original size of their order, too, by 23%. When we do credits, because its a better shopping experience, consumers end up buying more from participating stores, says Returnlys founder and CEO Eduardo Vilar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That makes total sense. So, financially, how are they doing? This sounds like a big operation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That makes total sense. So, financially, how are they doing? This sounds like a big operation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, they just raised nineteen million in Series B funding. Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder, he's actually involved. Total funding's up to like, thirty million now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, they just raised nineteen million in Series B funding. Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder, he's actually involved. Total funding's up to like, thirty million now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly announced on Wednesday that it has raised $19 million in a Series B funding round, led by venture capital firm Craft Ventures and with participation from Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder who currently runs Affirm. This brings the companys total funding up to $30 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, they're taking a cut on these transactions, I imagine? Or a subscription fee from retailers?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, they're taking a cut on these transactions, I imagine? Or a subscription fee from retailers?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Both! And here's the kicker: they actually assume the risk if a product is never returned.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Both! And here's the kicker: they actually assume the risk if a product is never returned.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has processed close to $200 million in returns in the last three years, taking a cut on each transaction. It also charges merchants an annual subscription fee. ... Returnly then assumes the risk that a product is never returned, whether thats because a customer fails to ship it back in the first place, it arrives damaged or it gets lost in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [gasps] Seriously? Like, if I just don't bother sending it back?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously? Like, if I just don't bother sending it back?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but they do try to, you know, nudge you with emails, or make it easier with printed labels. It's all about that customer data to assess risk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but they do try to, you know, nudge you with emails, or make it easier with printed labels. It's all about that customer data to assess risk.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In such an event, says Vilar, it can nudge a customer over email or try to make a return easier by sending a printed return label in the mail, for example, or scheduling the pickup of an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wild. So it's kind of like Affirm or Klarna, but for returns â€“ making it easier to spend and keep money flowing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wild. So it's kind of like Affirm or Klarna, but for returns - making it easier to spend and keep money flowing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most notably, companies like Affirm and Klarna frequently offer easy loans at checkout, with interest rates ranging from zero and going well into the double digits. Such financing has fueled online sales, which are expected to surpass $600 billion in the U.S. in 2019, according to eMarketer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. In this huge e-commerce world, where returns are, like, three times higher than in physical stores, it's a pretty brilliant niche.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. In this huge e-commerce world, where returns are, like, three times higher than in physical stores, it's a pretty brilliant niche.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Online purchases are three times more likely to be returned than those made in a physical store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. Instant gratification, instant revenue. Win-win for everyone, I guess, except maybe the person who *really* wanted to just get their cash back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. Instant gratification, instant revenue. Win-win for everyone, I guess, except maybe the person who really wanted to just get their cash back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The retailer gets a revenue-generating opportunity while the consumer gets instant gratification. ... Returnly offers store credit, rather than cash, in the hope that shoppers will spend the amount they are credited and then some.
